problem_text:
Can the question 7.28 on conditions for admissibility of an elementary carpet A = {Ar | r ∈ Φ} be reduced to Lie rank 1 if K is a field? A carpet A of type Φ of additive subgroups of K is called addmissible if in the Chevalley group over K associated with the root system Φ the subgroup ⟨xr(Ar) | r ∈ Φ⟩ intersects xr(K) in xr(Ar). More precisely, is it true that the carpet A is admissible if and only if the subcarpets {Ar, A−r}, r ∈ Φ, of rank 1 are admissible? The answer is known to be affirmative if the field K is locally finite (V. M. Levchuk, Algebra and Logic, 22, no. 5 (1983), 362–371).
V. M. Levchuk
